title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Within an hour, Lady Scott, disguised as a peasant, and carrying abasket on her arm, set out for Elibank, accompanied by the fairstranger.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: But do you not thinkthat it is possible that I could accompany ye to Elibank?

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: "My mother, my honoured mother,--Fate has delivered me into the power ofMurray of Elibank, the enemy of our house.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: "Then," cried she, and wept, "the days o' my winsome Willie arenumbered, and his death is determined on; for often has Sir Gideondeclared he would gie a' the lands o' Elibank for his head.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The mother of the laird sat in the midst of her daughters, mourning forhim, and looking from the window of the tower, as though, in every formthat appeared in the distance, she expected to see him, or at least togather tidings regarding him, when information was brought to her thathe was the prisoner of Murray of Elibank.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: I think, sir, thatit is due to the daughter o' a Murray o' Elibank, that she should becourted before she gies her hand.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Let him fulfil his purpose--I will die; but my deathshall be revenged; and tell my mother that it was my latest injunctionthat she should command every follower of our house to avenge her son'sdeath, while there is a Murray left in all Scotland to repent the deedo' the knight o' Elibank."

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: And ye, SirGideon," added he, turning towards the old knight, "in your amazingmercy and generosity, would spare my life, upon condition that I shouldmarry your _bonny_ daughter Meg! Look ye, sir--I am Scott o' Harden, andye are Murray o' Elibank; there is no love lost between us; chance hasplaced my life in your hands--take it, for I wouldna marry your daughterthough ye should gie me life, and a' the lands o' Elibank into thebargain.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: And ye, SirGideon," added he, turning towards the old knight, "in your amazingmercy and generosity, would spare my life, upon condition that I shouldmarry your _bonny_ daughter Meg! Look ye, sir--I am Scott o' Harden, andye are Murray o' Elibank; there is no love lost between us; chance hasplaced my life in your hands--take it, for I wouldna marry your daughterthough ye should gie me life, and a' the lands o' Elibank into thebargain.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Theold knight, therefore, commanded that they should be bound with cordstogether, and in such rueful plight led to his castle at Elibank.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: The laird, in order to repel any rescue thatmight be attempted, brought up the rear, and, in the joy of his heart,he sang, and, at times, cried aloud, "There will be dry breakfasts inElibank before the sun gets oot, but a merry meal at Oakwood afore hegangs doun.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: At their head was the fearless young laird; and, at a briskpace, they set off towards Elibank.

title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 02
author: Alexander Leighton
snippet: Now, every Murray among them has aweel-stocked mailing, and their kine are weel-favoured; to-night themoon is laughing cannily through the clouds:--therefore, what say ye,neighbours--will ye ride wi' me to Elibank?
